name: Collar
description: A normal, flat-buckle collar. 1" wide for large breeds, 3/4" for small breeds. My favorites: • Leather + steel: Hank's Leather • Leather + brass: Mendota • All-weather & thin: Tuff Pupper • All weather & thick: Regal

name: Leash
description: A 6 foot nylon leash that bends loosely and crumples easily in one hand. 3/4" wide is great. We want a floppy, easily bending leash. Avoid thick, rigid rope leashes or leashes with bulky handles.

name: Raised Platform
description: Measure first! If you have a small car trunk, consider one that folds up. If you get the Amazon brand and have wood floors get some rubber feet.

name: Treat Pouch
description: Get one that won't dangle in front of you when you bend over, isn't too deep for your fingers, and that is easily accessed with one hand. These washable silicone ones also work well.

name: Training Treats
description: When you can, use their kibble! When you can't, find a low calorie training treat that your dog likes. Costco sells these dried beef liver and dried salmon treats on the cheap in the pet section.

name: High-Value Treats
description: Use something your dog LOVES to reward recall. Costco sells huge packs of string cheese that work great.

name: Recall Whistle
description: A recall whistle has a specific frequency: 210.5 or 211.5 and no "pea" like the whistles they use in sports. Grab a lanyard too.

name: Long Line
description: This is how we safely practice recall and other "off leash" skills. These rubber-coated vinyl straps are strong, easy to clean, and lightweight. 50ft is a good length.

name: Long Line Tie Down
description: When you're working with your dog on a long line, a tie down spike can add an extra element of safety at a park.

name: Water Bowl (34oz)
description: This is in "The Basics" list because you need to bring water everywhere for your dog. Many of the ones on Amazon are deceptively small. Here's a link to some larger ones.

name: Ball-on-a-Rope
description: AKA the "crack ball." For high-drive dogs that could care less about treats, this is your reward system. The best (and cheapest) ones are from FoamDogBalls.com

name: Harness
description: One that gives full range of front legs without rubbing. Favorites: • Hurtta Y-Harness (by far). • RuffWear Front Range • Wilderdog

name: Avoid "step-in" style harnesses
description: Harnesses that connect with a single strap above the shoulder blades tend to restrict natural leg movement. Imagine a backpack that squeezed the side of your shoulder (where your arm rotates) and had a strap cutting through your arm pit. Instead, look for a harness that extends down the spine at least a little to ensure those front legs can slide freely alongside the body. I recommend watching this excellent video about dog anatomy and harnesses.
